title-group.article-title: Improved Formulas for Complete and Partial Summation of Certain Series

abstract.p: In two previous articles one of the authors gave formulas, with numerous examples, for summing a series either to infinity (complete) or up to a certain number n of terms (partial) by considering the sum of the first j terms S<sub>j</sub>, or some suitable modification S'<sub>j</sub>, closely related to S<sub>j</sub>, as a polynomial in 1/j. Either S<sub>∞</sub> or S<sub>n</sub> was found by m-point Lagrangian extrapolation from S<sub>j<sub>0</sub></sub>, S<sub>j<sub>0</sub>-1</sub>,⋯, S<sub>j<sub>0</sub>-m+1</sub> to 1/j = 0 or 1/j = 1/n respectively. This present paper furnishes more accurate m-point formulas for sums (or sequences) S<sub>j</sub> which behave as even functions of 1/j. Tables of Lagrangian extrapolation coefficients in the variable 1/j<sup>2</sup> are given for: complete summation, m = 2(1)7, j<sub>0</sub> = 10, exactly and 20D, m = 11, j<sub>0</sub> = 20, 30D; partial summation, m = 7, j<sub>0</sub> = 10, n = 11(1)25(5)100, 200, 500, 1000, exactly. Applications are made to calculating π or the semi-perimeters of many-sided regular polygons, Euler's constant, <tex-math>$1 + \sum_{r = 1}^j \Big\{\frac{-1}{(4r - 1)^2} + \frac{1}{(4r + 1)^2}\Big\} = 1 - \frac{1}{3^2} + \frac{1}{5^2} - \cdots \quad\text{for} j = \infty$</tex-math> (Catalan's constant), calculation of a definite integral as the limit of a suitably chosen sequence, determining later zeros of J<sub>ν</sub>(x) from earlier zeros for suitable ν, etc. A useful device in many cases involving sums of odd functions, is to replace S<sub>j</sub> by a trapezoidal-type S'<sub>j</sub> which is seen, from the Euler-Maclaurin formula, to be formally a series in 1/j<sup>2</sup>. In almost every example, comparison with the earlier (1/j)-extrapolation showed these present formulas, for 7 points, to improve results by anywhere from around 4 to 9 places.
